message.content:
cs.IT, cs.DS, cs.CC, cs.SI, cs.NT. 

The paper deals with the problem of characterizing representable polymatroids, which has connections to network coding and information theory. Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.IT (Information Theory). The paper also introduces a new approach to constructing polymatroids, which involves combining two existing polymatroids, making cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) another likely sub-category. The paper also discusses the Ingleton and Dougherty-Freiling-Zeger inequalities, which are related to combinatorics and optimization, respectively, suggesting cs.CC (Computational Complexity) and cs.SI (Social and Information Networks) as possible sub-categories. Finally, the paper uses mathematical techniques such as linear algebra and convex analysis, indicating cs.NT (Number Theory) as a potential sub-category.
